Statement\nPrint Overview\nThis project outlines a modular Information and Inventory Management System (IIMS) built using Visual Basic and Access database architecture. It integrates user registration, biometric validation, workbook protection, supplier-product relationships, and project scheduling. The system is designed for educational institutions, technical training centers, and administrative bodies requiring secure, traceable, and bilingual documentation.\n?? Description\nThe system includes:\n" VB Forms (Kfrm1-Kfrm6): Registration, address capture, login, password recovery, biometric scan\n" Database Tables: Supplier, Category, Product, Order, Customer, Employee\n" Workbook Protection: Track changes, restrict editing, recall messages\n" Project Scheduling: Marketing research, vendor selection, scope definition\n" SmartArt Diagrams: Visual flow from research ? concept ? feedback ? release\n" Certificate Management: Score reporting, testing center integration, license validation\n?? Visual Basic Code: Logigramme Logic for Training Diagnostics\n                                                    \nvb\n' Author: Tshingombe Tshitadi Fiston\n' Title: Logigramme Logic for Training Diagnostics\n' Purpose: Simulate decision-based logic for RSA compliance, trade theory integration, and LMS credential tracking\n                                                    \nSub TrainingLogigram()\n                                                    \n    ' === Initialization ===\n    Dim rsaValid As Boolean\n    Dim certificateExpiry As Date\n    Dim moduleCompleted As Boolean\n    Dim tradeTheoryAligned As Boolean\n    Dim auditReady As Boolean\n    Dim outputLog As String\n                                                    \n    ' === RSA Certificate Metadata ===\n    certificateExpiry = #3/7/2025#\n    rsaValid = (certificateExpiry \u003e Date)\n                                                    \n    ' === LMS Module Completion ===\n    moduleCompleted = True\n    tradeTheoryAligned = True\n                                                    \n    ' === Logigramme Decision Logic ===\n    If rsaValid Then\n        outputLog = \"RSA Certificate is valid. Portfolio is audit-ready.\"\n            Else\n                auditReady = False\n                outputLog = outputLog \u0026 vbCrLf \u0026 \"Module completed but not aligned with trade theory. Compliance alert triggered. Training diagnostics suspended.\"\n    End If\n                                                    \n    ' === Output ===\n    MsgBox outputLog, vbInformation, \"Training Diagnostic Logigramme\"\n                                                    \nEnd Sub\n                                                    \n?? Historiogram Equations for Behavioral Fusion\n                                                    \nFusion of User Behavior: $$ F_{ui} = w_o O_{ui} + w_a A_{ui} + w_b B_{ui} $$ Where OuiO_{ui}, AuiA_{ui}, and BuiB_{ui} are order, following, and browsing counts; weights wo=1w_o = 1, wa=0.5w_a = 0.5, wb=0.5w_b = 0.5\nCosine Similarity for User Fusion: $$ S_f(u,v) = \\cos(\\theta) = \\frac{F_u \\cdot F_v}{\\|F_u\\| \\|F_v\\|} $$\nTotal Similarity Score: $$ S(u,v) = S_f(u,v) + S_{bid}(u,v) + S_{nb}(u,v) + S_{item}(u,v) $$\nTop-K Recommendation Set: $$ RS_u = \\{i_1, i_2, ..., i_K\\} $$ Where KK is the mean of historical orders for user uu\n?? Initialize Credential Entry\nSub AddCredentialRecord()\n    Dim ws As Worksheet\n    Set ws = ThisWorkbook.Sheets(\"CredentialRecordBook\")\n\n    Dim nextRow As Long\n    nextRow = ws.Cells(ws.rows.count, \"A\").End(xlUp).row + 1\n\n    ' Sample input fields\n    Dim credentialID As String: credentialID = \"CE-PLUS-2025-001\"\n    Dim scheme As String: scheme = \"Cyber Essentials Plus\"\n    Dim issuer As String: issuer = \"IASME Consortium Ltd\"\n    Dim issueDate As Date: issueDate = DateSerial(2024, 12, 13)\n    Dim expiryDate As Date: expiryDate = DateSerial(2025, 12, 13)\n    Dim Status As String: Status = DetermineCredentialStatus(issueDate, expiryDate)\n    Dim inspectionDate As Date: inspectionDate = DateSerial(2025, 10, 21)\n    Dim amendmentNote As String: amendmentNote = \"Superseded by CE-PLUS-2026-001\"\n    Dim registryLink As String: registryLink = \"https://blockmarktech.com/certificates/\" \u0026 credentialID\n\n    ' Populate record book\n    With ws\n        .Cells(nextRow, 1).Value = credentialID\n        .Cells(nextRow, 2).Value = scheme\n        .Cells(nextRow, 3).Value = issuer\n        .Cells(nextRow, 4).Value = issueDate\n        .Cells(nextRow, 5).Value = expiryDate\n        .Cells(nextRow, 6).Value = Status\n        .Cells(nextRow, 7).Value = inspectionDate\n        .Cells(nextRow, 8).Value = amendmentNote\n        .Cells(nextRow, 9).Value = registryLink\n    End With\n\n    MsgBox \"Credential record added successfully.\", vbInformation\nEnd Sub\n?? 2. Concept: Automating a CI Job in VBA\nLet's say you want to simulate a CI (Continuous Integration) job in VBA that:\n1.  Checks out a repository\n2.  Runs a one-line script\n3. Concept: Automating a CI Job in VBA\nLet's say you want to simulate a CI (Continuous Integration) job in VBA that:\n1.  Checks out a repository\n2.  Runs a one-line script\n3.  Runs a multi-line script\n4.  Logs post-run cleanup\n5.  Completes the job\n?? 1. Logigramme (Logic Diagram)\nThis shows the decision flow and sequence of operations:\nplaintext\n[Start]\n   Print\n[Trigger: Push or PR to 'main']\n   Print\n[Initialize Job]\n   Print\n[Checkout Repository]\n   Print\n[Run One-Line Script]\n   Print\n[Run Multi-Line Script]\n   Print\n[Post-Run Cleanup]\n   Print\n[Complete Job]\n   Print\nEnd\n?? 2. Algorigramme (Algorithm Diagram)\nThis shows the procedural logic in structured pseudocode or VBA logic blocks:\nvb\n\n    If TriggeredByPushOrPR() Then\n        Call CheckoutRepo\n        Call RunOneLineScript\n        Call RunMultiLineScript\n        Call PostRunCleanup\n        MsgBox \"CI Job Completed\"\n    Else\n        MsgBox \"No trigger detected.\"\n    End If\nEnd Sub\n\n\n    ' Simulate trigger condition\n    TriggeredByPushOrPR = True\nEnd Function\n\n    Debug.Print \"Repository checked out.\"\nEnd Sub\n\n    Debug.Print \"Hello, world!\"\nEnd Sub\n\n\n    Debug.Print \"Add other actions to build,\"\n    Debug.Print \"test, and deploy your project.\"\nEnd Sub\n\n    Debug.Print \"Post-run cleanup complete.\"\nEnd Sub\n?? Role Overview: Engineering Director at Salesforce\nThe Engineering Director leads high-performing software engineering teams, aligning cloud strategy with customer success. Incomplete\") \u0026 vbCrLf\n    Next i\n    MsgBox Output, vbInformation, \"Outcome Tracker\"\nEnd Sub\n\n    If index \u003e= 1 And index \u003c= 4 Then\n        outcomes(index).Completed = True\n        MsgBox \"Marked Outcome \" \u0026 index \u0026 \" as complete.\", vbInformation\n    Else\n        MsgBox \"Invalid outcome index.\", vbExclamation\n    End If\nEnd Sub\n\nFunction CalculateCharacteristicImpedance(L As Double, C As Double) As Double\n    ' Z0 = sqrt(L/C)\n    CalculateCharacteristicImpedance = Sqr(L / C)\nEnd Function\n\nFunction CalculateVelocity(L As Double, C As Double) As Double\n    ' v = 1 / sqrt(L*C)\n    CalculateVelocity = 1 / Sqr(L * C)\nEnd Function\n\nSub ShowParameterCalculations()\n    Dim L As Double, C As Double\n    L = InputBox(\"Enter inductance per unit length (H/m):\")\n    C = InputBox(\"Enter capacitance per unit length (F/m):\")\n    \n    Dim Z0 As Double, v As Double\n    Z0 = CalculateCharacteristicImpedance(L, C)\n    v = CalculateVelocity(L, C)\n    \n    MsgBox \"Calculated Parameters:\" \u0026 vbCrLf \u0026 _\n           \"Characteristic Impedance (Z0): \" \u0026 Format(Z0, \"0.00\") \u0026 \" ?\" \u0026 vbCrLf \u0026 _\n           \"Velocity of Propagation (v): \" \u0026 Format(v, \"0.00\") \u0026 \" m/s\", vbInformation\nEnd Sub\n?? Visual Basic Code: Nodal Analysis \u0026 PWM Calculator\nThis VBA module supports:\n\"   Calculating R1 and R2 for a Schmitt trigger using nodal analysis\n\"   Determining PWM frequency and duty cycle from ADC input\nvb\n' Module: Q10_BoomArm_Amplifier_PWM\n' Purpose: Solve nodal analysis for R1/R2 and calculate PWM duty cycle\n\nOption Explicit\n\n' Calculate R1 and R2 for Schmitt trigger thresholds\nFunction CalculateResistorRatio(VsatHigh As Double, VsatLow As Double, VthHigh As Double, VthLow As Double) As String\n    ' Using nodal analysis:\n    ' Vth = Vsat * (R2 / (R1 + R2)) =\u003e R2/R1 = Vth / (Vsat - Vth)\n    Dim ratioHigh As Double, ratioLow As Double\n    ratioHigh = VthHigh / (VsatHigh - VthHigh)\n    ratioLow = VthLow / (VsatLow - VthLow)\n    \n    CalculateResistorRatio = \"R2/R1 for Vth+ = \" \u0026 Format(ratioHigh, \"0.00\") \u0026 vbCrLf \u0026 _\n                             \"R2/R1 for Vth? = \" \u0026 Format(ratioLow, \"0.00\")\nEnd Function\n\n' Calculate R1 and R2 given parallel resistance and one known resistor\nFunction CalculateResistorPair(Rparallel As Double, Rknown As Double) As Double\n    ' Rparallel = (R1 * R2) / (R1 + R2)\n    ' Solve for R2 given R1\n    CalculateResistorPair = (Rparallel * Rknown) / (Rknown - Rparallel)\nEnd Function\n\n' Calculate PWM duty cycle and frequency\nFunction CalculatePWM(pos As Integer, totalTime_us As Double) As String\n    Dim onTime As Double, offTime As Double, period_us As Double\n    onTime = pos\n    offTime = 2000 - pos\n    period_us = onTime + offTime\n    Dim freq As Double, duty As Double\n    freq = 1000000 / period_us\n    duty = (onTime / period_us) * 100\n    CalculatePWM = \"Frequency: \" \u0026 Format(freq, \"0.00\") \u0026 \" Hz\" \u0026 vbCrLf \u0026 _\n                   \"Duty Cycle: \" \u0026 Format(duty, \"0.0\") \u0026 \"%\"\nEnd Function\n?? Example Usage\nvb\nSub RunQ10Calculations()\n    ' Part (f) - Resistor ratio for Schmitt trigger\n    MsgBox CalculateResistorRatio(7.5, 0, 5.2, 2.7)\n\n    ' Part (e) - R1 = 8.25k?, find R2 for parallel = 85k?\n    Dim R2 As Double\n    R2 = CalculateResistorPair(85000, 8250)\n    MsgBox \"R2 = \" \u0026 Format(R2 / 1000, \"0.00\") \u0026 \" k?\"\n\n    ' Part (g) - PWM from ADC input\n    MsgBox CalculatePWM(1044, 40000) ' pos = 1044 ?s, total = 40 ms\nEnd Sub\nWould you like this extended to include graphical plotting of the load line, bending moment diagrams, or export to a credential-linked engineering dashboard?\nCopilot said\nHere 's a scoped overview, structured description, and Visual Basic code module tailored to the 2024 Advanced Higher Engineering Science Finalised Marking Instructions. Visual Basic Code: Structural \u0026 Control Calculators\nThis VBA module supports bending moment calculations, ADC resolution, and gear force analysis.\nvb\n' Module: AH_EngScience2023_Calculators\n' Purpose: Support structural and control system calculations for Q7-Q9\n\nOption Explicit\n\n' Calculate maximum permissible bending moment\nFunction MaxBendingMoment(stress As Double, Ixx As Double, y As Double, safetyFactor As Double) As Double\n    ' M = (?  I) / y  (1 / safetyFactor)\n    MaxBendingMoment = (stress * Ixx / y) / safetyFactor\nEnd Function\n\n' Calculate span from bending moment\nFunction MaxSpan(M As Double, w As Double) As Double\n    ' M = (w  L) / 8 ? L = sqrt(8M / w)\n    MaxSpan = Sqr((8 * M) / w)\nEnd Function\n\n' Calculate ADC resolution and digital value\nFunction ADCResolution(bits As Integer, peakVoltage As Double) As Double\n    ADCResolution = (peakVoltage * 1000) / (2 ^ bits)\nEnd Function\n\nFunction ADCValue(inputVoltage As Double, peakVoltage As Double, bits As Integer) As Integer\n    ADCValue = Int((inputVoltage / peakVoltage) * (2 ^ bits - 1))\nEnd Function\n\n' Calculate tangential and radial gear forces\nFunction GearForces(powerWatts As Double, rpm As Double, radius_mm As Double, pressureAngle_deg As Double) As String\n    Dim omega As Double, torque As Double, Ft As Double, Fr As Double\n    omega = (2 * WorksheetFunction.pi() * rpm) / 60\n    torque = powerWatts / omega\n    Ft = torque / (radius_mm / 1000)\n    Fr = Ft * Tan(pressureAngle_deg * WorksheetFunction.pi() / 180)\n    GearForces = \"Tangential: \" \u0026 Format(Ft, \"0.00\") \u0026 \" N, Radial: \" \u0026 Format(Fr, \"0.00\") \u0026 \" N\"\nEnd Function\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n \n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n  \n \n  \n\n\n\n\n\n  \n \n   \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n \n\n\n  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n### Tag message\n\nerg\n"}}

Historiogram Equations for Behavioral Fusion\n                                                    \nFusion of User Behavior: $$ F_{ui} = w_o O_{ui} + w_a A_{ui} + w_b B_{ui} $$ Where OuiO_{ui}, AuiA_{ui}, and BuiB_{ui} are order, following, and browsing counts; weights wo=1w_o = 1, wa=0.5w_a = 0.5, wb=0.5w_b = 0.5\nCosine Similarity for User Fusion: $$ S_f(u,v) = \\cos(\\theta) = \\frac{F_u \\cdot F_v}{\\|F_u\\| \\|F_v\\|} $$\nTotal Similarity Score: $$ S(u,v) = S_f(u,v) + S_{bid}(u,v) + S_{nb}(u,v) + S_{item}(u,v) $$\nTop-K Recommendation Set: $$ RS_u = \\{i_1, i_2, ..., i_K\\} $$ Where KK is the mean of historical orders for user uu\n?? Initialize Credential Entry\nSub AddCredentialRecord()\n    Dim ws As Worksheet\n    Set ws = ThisWorkbook.Sheets(\"CredentialRecordBook\")\n\n    Dim nextRow As Long\n    nextRow = ws.Cells(ws.rows.count, \"A\").End(xlUp).row + 1\n\n    ' Sample input fields\n    Dim credentialID As String: credentialID = \"CE-PLUS-2025-001\"\n    Dim scheme As String: scheme = \"Cyber Essentials Plus\"\n    Dim issuer As String: issuer = \"IASME Consortium Ltd\"\n    Dim issueDate As Date: issueDate = DateSerial(2024, 12, 13)\n    Dim expiryDate As Date: expiryDate = DateSerial(2025, 12, 13)\n    Dim Status As String: Status = DetermineCredentialStatus(issueDate, expiryDate)\n    Dim inspectionDate As Date: inspectionDate = DateSerial(2025, 10, 21)\n    Dim amendmentNote As String: amendmentNote = \"Superseded by CE-PLUS-2026-001\"\n    Dim registryLink As String: registryLink = \"https://blockmarktech.com/certificates/\" \u0026 credentialID\n\n    ' Populate record book\n    With ws\n        .Cells(nextRow, 1).Value = credentialID\n        .Cells(nextRow, 2).Value = scheme\n        .Cells(nextRow, 3).Value = issuer\n        .Cells(nextRow, 4).Value = issueDate\n        .Cells(nextRow, 5).Value = expiryDate\n        .Cells(nextRow, 6).Value = Status\n        .Cells(nextRow, 7).Value = inspectionDate\n        .Cells(nextRow, 8).Value = amendmentNote\n        .Cells(nextRow, 9).Value = registryLink\n    End With\n\n    MsgBox \"Credential record added successfully.\", vbInformation\nEnd Sub\n?? 2. Credential Status Logic (Logigramme)\nvb\nFunction DetermineCredentialStatus(issueDate As Date, expiryDate As Date) As String\n    If Date \u003e expiryDate Then\n        DetermineCredentialStatus = \"Expired\"\n    ElseIf Date \u003e= DateAdd(\"m\", -1, expiryDate) Then\n        DetermineCredentialStatus = \"Expiring Soon\"\n    Else\n        DetermineCredentialStatus = \"Active\"\n    End If\nEnd Function\n?? 3. Amendment Tracker (Algorigramme Logic)\nSub TrackAmendments()\n    Dim ws As Worksheet: Set ws = ThisWorkbook.Sheets(\"CredentialRecordBook\")\n    Dim lastRow As Long: lastRow = ws.Cells(ws.rows.count, \"A\").End(xlUp).row\n\n    Dim i As Long\n    For i = 2 To lastRow\n        If ws.Cells(i, 6).Value = \"Superseded\" Then\n            ws.Cells(i, 8).Interior.Color = RGB(255, 255, 0) ' Highlight amendment note\n        End If\n    Next i\n\n    MsgBox \"Amendment tracking complete.\", vbInformation\nEnd Sub\nWould you like this expanded into a bilingual UserForm interface, linked to CPD folders, or integrated with BlockMark inspection logs and hash stamping logic? Concept: Automating a CI Job in VBA\nLet's say you want to simulate a CI (Continuous Integration) job in VBA that:\n1.  Checks out a repository\n2.  Runs a one-line script\n3.  Runs a multi-line script\n4.  Logs post-run cleanup\n5.  Completes the job\n?? 1. Logigramme (Logic Diagram)\nThis shows the decision flow and sequence of operations:\nplaintext\n[Start]\n   Print\n[Trigger: Push or PR to 'main']\n   Print\n[Initialize Job]\n   Print\n[Checkout Repository]\n   Print\n[Run One-Line Script]\n   Print\n[Run Multi-Line Script]\n   Print\n[Post-Run Cleanup]\n   Print\n[Complete Job]\n   Print\nEnd\n?? 2. Algorigramme (Algorithm Diagram)\nThis shows the procedural logic in structured pseudocode or VBA logic blocks:\nvb\nSub RunCIJob()\n    If TriggeredByPushOrPR() Then\n        Call CheckoutRepo\n        Call RunOneLineScript\n        Call RunMultiLineScript\n        Call PostRunCleanup\n        MsgBox \"CI Job Completed\"\n    Else\n        MsgBox \"No trigger detected.\"\n    End If\nEnd Sub\n\nFunction TriggeredByPushOrPR() As Boolean\n    ' Simulate trigger condition\n    TriggeredByPushOrPR = True\nEnd Function\n\n\n    Debug.Print \"Repository checked out.\"\nEnd Sub\n\n\n    Debug.Print \"Hello, world!\"\nEnd Sub\n\n\n    Debug.Print \"Add other actions to build,\"\n    Debug.Print \"test, and deploy your project.\"\nEnd Sub\n\n    Debug.Print \"Post-run cleanup complete.\"\nEnd Sub\n?? Role Overview: Engineering Director at Salesforce\nThe Engineering Director leads high-performing software engineering teams, aligning cloud strategy with customer success. This role blends technical leadership, product delivery, and people management across distributed systems and agile environments.\n?? This is especially useful for your credential-linked dashboards, audit sheets, or public service workflows.\n?? Concept: Automating a CI Job in VBA\nLet's say you want to simulate a CI (Continuous Integration) job in VBA that:\n1.  Checks out a repository\n2.  Runs a one-line script\n3.  Runs a multi-line script\n4.  Logs post-run cleanup\n5.  Completes the job\n?? 1. Logigramme (Logic Diagram)\nThis shows the decision flow and sequence of operations:\nplaintext\n[Start]\n   Print\n[Trigger: Push or PR to 'main']\n   Print\n[Initialize Job]\n   Print\n[Checkout Repository]\n   Print\n[Run One-Line Script]\n   Print\n[Run Multi-Line Script]\n   Print\n[Post-Run Cleanup]\n   Print\n[Complete Job]\n   Print\nEnd\n?? 2. Concept: Automating a CI Job in VBA\nLet's say you want to simulate a CI (Continuous Integration) job in VBA that:\n1.  Checks out a repository\n2.  Runs a one-line script\n3. Logigramme (Logic Diagram)\nThis shows the decision flow and sequence of operations:\nplaintext\n[Start]\n   Print\n[Trigger: Push or PR to 'main']\n   Print\n[Initialize Job]\n   Print\n[Checkout Repository]\n   Print\n[Run One-Line Script]\n   Print\n[Run Multi-Line Script]\n   Print\n[Post-Run Cleanup]\n   Print\n[Complete Job]\n   Print\nEnd\n?? 2. Algorigramme (Algorithm Diagram)\nThis shows the procedural logic in structured pseudocode or VBA logic blocks:\nvb\n\n    If TriggeredByPushOrPR() Then\n        Call CheckoutRepo\n        Call RunOneLineScript\n        Call RunMultiLineScript\n        Call PostRunCleanup\n        MsgBox \"CI Job Completed\"\n    Else\n        MsgBox \"No trigger detected.\"\n    End If\nEnd Sub\n\n\n    ' Simulate trigger condition\n    TriggeredByPushOrPR = True\nEnd Function\n\n    Debug.Print \"Repository checked out.\"\nEnd Sub\n\n    Debug.Print \"Hello, world!\"\nEnd Sub\n\n\n    Debug.Print \"Add other actions to build,\"\n    Debug.Print \"test, and deploy your project.\"\nEnd Sub\n\n    Debug.Print \"Post-run cleanup complete.\"\nEnd Sub\n?? Incomplete\") \u0026 vbCrLf\n    Next i\n    MsgBox Output, vbInformation, \"Outcome Tracker\"\nEnd Sub\n\n    If index \u003e= 1 And index \u003c= 4 Then\n        outcomes(index).Completed = True\n        MsgBox \"Marked Outcome \" \u0026 index \u0026 \" as complete.\", vbInformation\n    Else\n        MsgBox \"Invalid outcome index.\", vbExclamation\n    End If\nEnd Sub\n\nFunction CalculateCharacteristicImpedance(L As Double, C As Double) As Double\n    ' Z0 = sqrt(L/C)\n    CalculateCharacteristicImpedance = Sqr(L / C)\nEnd Function\n\nFunction CalculateVelocity(L As Double, C As Double) As Double\n    ' v = 1 / sqrt(L*C)\n    CalculateVelocity = 1 / Sqr(L * C)\nEnd Function\n\nSub ShowParameterCalculations()\n    Dim L As Double, C As Double\n    L = InputBox(\"Enter inductance per unit length (H/m):\")\n    C = InputBox(\"Enter capacitance per unit length (F/m):\")\n    \n    Dim Z0 As Double, v As Double\n    Z0 = CalculateCharacteristicImpedance(L, C)\n    v = CalculateVelocity(L, C)\n    \n    MsgBox \"Calculated Parameters:\" \u0026 vbCrLf \u0026 _\n           \"Characteristic Impedance (Z0): \" \u0026 Format(Z0, \"0.00\") \u0026 \" ?\" \u0026 vbCrLf \u0026 _\n           \"Velocity of Propagation (v): \" \u0026 Format(v, \"0.00\") \u0026 \" m/s\", vbInformation\nEnd Sub\n?? Visual Basic Code: Nodal Analysis \u0026 PWM Calculator\nThis VBA module supports:\n\"   Calculating R1 and R2 for a Schmitt trigger using nodal analysis\n\"   Determining PWM frequency and duty cycle from ADC input\nvb\n' Module: Q10_BoomArm_Amplifier_PWM\n' Purpose: Solve nodal analysis for R1/R2 and calculate PWM duty cycle\n\nOption Explicit\n\n' Calculate R1 and R2 for Schmitt trigger thresholds\nFunction CalculateResistorRatio(VsatHigh As Double, VsatLow As Double, VthHigh As Double, VthLow As Double) As String\n    ' Using nodal analysis:\n    ' Vth = Vsat * (R2 / (R1 + R2)) =\u003e R2/R1 = Vth / (Vsat - Vth)\n    Dim ratioHigh As Double, ratioLow As Double\n    ratioHigh = VthHigh / (VsatHigh - VthHigh)\n    ratioLow = VthLow / (VsatLow - VthLow)\n    \n    CalculateResistorRatio = \"R2/R1 for Vth+ = \" \u0026 Format(ratioHigh, \"0.00\") \u0026 vbCrLf \u0026 _\n                             \"R2/R1 for Vth? = \" \u0026 Format(ratioLow, \"0.00\")\nEnd Function\n\n' Calculate R1 and R2 given parallel resistance and one known resistor\nFunction CalculateResistorPair(Rparallel As Double, Rknown As Double) As Double\n    ' Rparallel = (R1 * R2) / (R1 + R2)\n    ' Solve for R2 given R1\n    CalculateResistorPair = (Rparallel * Rknown) / (Rknown - Rparallel)\nEnd Function\n\n' Calculate PWM duty cycle and frequency\nFunction CalculatePWM(pos As Integer, totalTime_us As Double) As String\n    Dim onTime As Double, offTime As Double, period_us As Double\n    onTime = pos\n    offTime = 2000 - pos\n    period_us = onTime + offTime\n    Dim freq As Double, duty As Double\n    freq = 1000000 / period_us\n    duty = (onTime / period_us) * 100\n    CalculatePWM = \"Frequency: \" \u0026 Format(freq, \"0.00\") \u0026 \" Hz\" \u0026 vbCrLf \u0026 _\n                   \"Duty Cycle: \" \u0026 Format(duty, \"0.0\") \u0026 \"%\"\nEnd Function\n?? Example Usage\nvb\nSub RunQ10Calculations()\n    ' Part (f) - Resistor ratio for Schmitt trigger\n    MsgBox CalculateResistorRatio(7.5, 0, 5.2, 2.7)\n\n    ' Part (e) - R1 = 8.25k?, find R2 for parallel = 85k?\n    Dim R2 As Double\n    R2 = CalculateResistorPair(85000, 8250)\n    MsgBox \"R2 = \" \u0026 Format(R2 / 1000, \"0.00\") \u0026 \" k?\"\n\n    ' Part (g) - PWM from ADC input\n    MsgBox CalculatePWM(1044, 40000) ' pos = 1044 ?s, total = 40 ms\nEnd Sub\nWould you like this extended to include graphical plotting of the load line, bending moment diagrams, or export to a credential-linked engineering dashboard?\nCopilot said\nHere 's a scoped overview, structured description, and Visual Basic code module tailored to the 2024 Advanced Higher Engineering Science Finalised Marking Instructions. Visual Basic Code: Structural \u0026 Control Calculators\nThis VBA module supports bending moment calculations, ADC resolution, and gear force analysis.\nvb\n' Module: AH_EngScience2023_Calculators\n' Purpose: Support structural and control system calculations for Q7-Q9\n\nOption Explicit\n\n' Calculate maximum permissible bending moment\nFunction MaxBendingMoment(stress As Double, Ixx As Double, y As Double, safetyFactor As Double) As Double\n    ' M = (?  I) / y  (1 / safetyFactor)\n    MaxBendingMoment = (stress * Ixx / y) / safetyFactor\nEnd Function\n\n' Calculate span from bending moment\nFunction MaxSpan(M As Double, w As Double) As Double\n    ' M = (w  L) / 8 ? L = sqrt(8M / w)\n    MaxSpan = Sqr((8 * M) / w)\nEnd Function\n\n' Calculate ADC resolution and digital value\nFunction ADCResolution(bits As Integer, peakVoltage As Double) As Double\n    ADCResolution = (peakVoltage * 1000) / (2 ^ bits)\nEnd Function\n\nFunction ADCValue(inputVoltage As Double, peakVoltage As Double, bits As Integer) As Integer\n    ADCValue = Int((inputVoltage / peakVoltage) * (2 ^ bits - 1))\nEnd Function\n\n' Calculate tangential and radial gear forces\nFunction GearForces(powerWatts As Double, rpm As Double, radius_mm As Double, pressureAngle_deg As Double) As String\n    Dim omega As Double, torque As Double, Ft As Double, Fr As Double\n    omega = (2 * WorksheetFunction.pi() * rpm) / 60\n    torque = powerWatts / omega\n    Ft = torque / (radius_mm / 1000)\n    Fr = Ft * Tan(pressureAngle_deg * WorksheetFunction.pi() / 180)\n    GearForces = \"Tangential: \" \u0026 Format(Ft, \"0.00\") \u0026 \" N, Radial: \" \u0026 Format(Fr, \"0.00\") \u0026 \" N\"\nEnd Function\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n \n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n  \n \n  \n\n\n\n\n\n  \n \n   \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n \n\n\n  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n### Tag message\n\nerg\n"}}

                                                    Job Description
                                                    As a Product Designer, you will work within a Product Delivery Team fused with UX, engineering, product and data talent. You will help the team design beautiful interfaces that solve business challenges for our clients. We work with a number of Tier 1 banks on building web-based applications for AML, KYC and Sanctions List management workflows. This role is ideal if you are looking to segue your career into the FinTech or Big Data arenas.
                                                    Key Responsibilities

                                                        Be involved in every step of the product design cycle from discovery to developer handoff and user acceptance testing.
                                                        Work with BAs, product managers and tech teams to lead the Product Design
                                                        Maintain quality of the design process and ensure that when designs are translated into code they accurately reflect the design specifications.
                                                        Accurately estimate design tickets during planning sessions.
                                                        Contribute to sketching sessions involving non-designersCreate, iterate and maintain UI deliverables including sketch files, style guides, high fidelity prototypes, micro interaction specifications and pattern libraries.
                                                        Ensure design choices are data led by identifying assumptions to test each sprint, and work with the analysts in your team to plan moderated usability test sessions.
                                                        Design pixel perfect responsive UIs and understand that adopting common interface patterns is better for UX than reinventing the wheel
                                                        Present your work to the wider business at Show & Tell sessions.

                                                    Skill & Experience

                                                        You have at least 3 years experience working as a Product Designer.
                                                        You have experience using Sketch and InVision or Framer X
                                                        You have some previous experience working in an agile environment  Think two-week sprints.

                                                                                        Methods of Assessment

                                                                                        Now we will take a more detailed look at common methods of assessment used in vocational assessments. Highlighted is their advantages, limitations and some construction features you need to consider if developing that method of assessment.

                                                                                        More methods of assessment are covered within Assessment: A Guide for Centres offering Regulated Qualifications(opens in a new tab).

                                                                                        As you become more familiar with the various assessment methods you will begin to identify what is a natural fit for the assessment you are developing.

                                                                                            For example, in the vocational context some assessment methods will be an obvious choice and pair well with naturally occurring evidence from the workplace. Alternatively, you might find industry stipulations will dictate the assessment method, for example a First Aid at Work qualification requires learners to undertake a practical activity, such as performing CPR on a manikin.

                                                                                        Portfolio

                                                                                        A portfolio is a means of presenting evidence of learner achievement.

                                                                                        It is a representative collection of different pieces of evidence of a learners skills, knowledge, understanding and competence which indicates that they have met the requirements of a qualification.

                                                                                        They can be produced in a range of media, and these days e-portfolios or cloud-based software are becoming the norm when compiling and storing portfolios.

                                                                                            

                                                                                            Portfolios are also appropriate for subjects with strong practical and/or creative content.

                                                                                            Can be used to collect naturally-occurring evidence.

                                                                                            Provides the learner with the opportunity to demonstrate personal initiative.

                                                                                            Allows the inclusion of photographic/electronic evidence.

                                                                                            Allows considerable scope for personalisation.

                                                                                            Can provide the opportunity to integrate assessment.

                                                                                        Continued

                                                                                        Practical Activity

                                                                                        A practical activity consists of any activity that allows learners to demonstrate their technical, artistic and creative skills.

                                                                                        The assessment may be based on the end-result of the activity (the product), or the carrying-out of the activity (the process), or a combination of both.

                                                                                        In the assessment of vocational qualifications this is commonly known as Observation and is noted to be one of the most valid and reliable methods of assessment.

                                                                                        In some subjects, demonstrating a practical skill can show that learners can apply the knowledge needed to demonstrate competence. In other subjects, the underpinning knowledge may not be so clearly apparent. In such cases, an additional assessment such as questioning may be required to supplement any observation of the skill.

                                                                                            

                                                                                            Practical activities allow learners to display their specialised skills and techniques and can provide evidence of practical skills gained, for example, in the workplace.

                                                                                            Assesses real-life skills.

                                                                                            The completion of an artefact/product/service provides tangible evidence of achievement.

                                                                                            Practical activity can be very motivating for learners.

                                                                                            May be used to integrate assessment across outcomes and units.

                                                                                        Continued

                                                                                        Performance

                                                                                        Performance is a particular type of practical activity that is used for the assessment of skills where the evidence is fleeting.

                                                                                        It allows learners to demonstrate their abilities and skills and so the process is normally the focus of the assessment, although the quality of the performance as a finished product may also be assessed. Again, this type of assessment method is commonly referred to as Observation in the vocational sector.

                                                                                        In some cases, the learner will also be required to analyse and reflect upon their performance, for example by providing a commentary or personal statement, and this product may also be assessed.

                                                                                            

                                                                                            Provides evidence of skills in music/dance/drama/sporting activities.

                                                                                            Assesses skills in a live environment.

                                                                                            Can be very motivating for learners.

                                                                                            May be used to integrate assessment.

                                                                                        Continued

                                                                                        Reflective Reports/Accounts

                                                                                        Reflective reports are sometimes called reflective accounts or personal statements.

                                                                                        They are used to elicit how a learner completed an activity in a certain way or how they produced a product of their work.

                                                                                            

                                                                                            Reflective reports can help identify knowledge and understanding that the learner has that might not be obvious from an observation or a product they have created.

                                                                                            Can be used to confirm knowledge.

                                                                                            Can be used to integrate assessment.

                                                                                            Learners produce reflective reports and are free to do so in any way that befits their product or observation evidence.

                                                                                            This assessment is wide-ranging and can cover outcomes from a number of units.

                                                                                        Continued

                                                                                        Professional Discussion

                                                                                        A professional discussion between a learner and an assessor focuses on evidence already provided or demonstrated by the learner.

                                                                                        This is likely to consist of real work activities, practical tasks, a case study, project, portfolio or some other form of assessment.

                                                                                        The assessor starts by asking the learner questions about the evidence, and a discussion ensues. The assessor must record the discussion. The assessor is responsible for ensuring that the points that need to be covered are brought into the discussion by the learner.

                                                                                        A professional discussion is not a substitute for the demonstration of skills. The learner needs to be able to show the assessor how what they say in the discussion is backed up in other ways.

                                                                                        This could be, for example, by product evidence, witness testimonies, workplace documents or other material either developed though work or in other assessments.

                                                                                            

                                                                                            Suitable for assessing higher-order analytical and decision-making skills.

                                                                                            The assessor is able to target particular areas for discussion and can gain additional evidence while the assessment is in progress.

                                                                                            The professional discussion can be used to integrate assessment.

                                                                                            Helps to make use of naturally-occurring evidence in the assessment of some higher-order vocational learning.

                                                                                            Assessment Development Fundamentals

                                                                                            Developing Multiple Choice Assessments for HN/VQ 

                                                                                        Developing Multiple Choice Assessments for HN/VQ
                                                                                        Completion requirements
                                                                                        To do: Complete or pass the activity

                                                                                        Before completing this module, you must complete the following modules:

                                                                                            Developing Vocational SQA Assessments (for the externally regulated market)

                                                                                            Selecting valid assessment methods

                                                                                        This module is designed to support SQA staff and Qualification Development Specialists (QDS) in developing Multiple Choice Question (MCQ) assessments.

                                                                                        By completing this module, you will:

                                                                                            Become familiar with the purpose of Multiple Choice Question (MCQ) Assessments

                                                                                            Gain knowledge on how to identify valid content for the assessment method

                                                                                            Be provided with guidance on how to develop your own MCQs.

                                                                                            Be provided with an overview of the SQA assessment development process.

                                                                                        Throughout the module there will be some reflection points to consolidate your knowledge and understanding these will prepare you for developing your own assessments.

                                                                                        MCQs are a tried and tested assessment method and are widely used across SQAs many qualifications.  This module will focus on their use within our HN/VQ portfolio.

                                                                                        MCQ assessments can be easily administered within a digital or paper assessment. Currently, there are SQA developed MCQ assessments available on SOLAR and the SQA Secure Site across a variety of subject areas for example, Construction and Professional Taxi and Private Hire Driver at SCQF level 5.

                                                                                        MCQ assessments can be used to record a learners starting point, measure progress (formative assessment and feedback) and if used at the end of the unit (summative assessment) it can evidence their knowledge recall from their learning. The majority of our MCQ assessments are provided for summative assessments, and often confer licences to practice for example,  Health and Safety in a Construction Environment Award at SCQF level 4.

                                                                                        Regulated qualifications

                                                                                        Regulated qualifications

                                                                                        Regulated qualifications refer to qualifications externally regulated in Scotland, England and Wales.

                                                                                        Beyond our externally regulated provision we have a large and varied portfolio of qualifications, which we self regulate via our Code of Practice and Governing Principles.

                                                                                        There are three external regulators that recognise SQA qualifications:

                                                                                            1

                                                                                            SQA Accreditation for qualifications offered in Scotland
                                                                                            2

                                                                                            Ofqual for qualifications offered in England
                                                                                            3

                                                                                            Qualifications Wales for qualifications offered in Wales.

                                                                                        When you are developing a regulated assessment, depending on where the qualification and associated assessment will be delivered you must make sure it is in line with SQA Accreditations Regulatory Principles, Ofquals General Conditions of Recognition or Qualification Wales Standard Conditions of Recognition.                                                                                         What is assessment?

                                                                                        What is assessment?

                                                                                        Assessment is the process of evaluating an individuals attainment of knowledge, understanding, skills and competences. It has many uses, but these can be divided into two major categories: uses for individual learners and uses for external organisations.

                                                                                            Section 5 - Principles of assessment
                                                                                            Section 6 of 13
                                                                                            Validity

                                                                                            Validity

                                                                                            Validity is a measure of accuracy of an assessment. An assessment is valid when it:
                                                                                                

                                                                                                allows the interpretation and inferences which can be drawn from the assessment outcomes to be meaningful and justifiable.

                                                                                            Validity must be ensured at each stage of the assessment process.

                                                                                            A good example of a valid assessment, is the universal driving test: the learner is asked to demonstrate their driving skills and competence in the presence of an examiner, and they are also required to prove their knowledge of the Highway Code via the theory test.

                                                                                            Key aspects of validity

                                                                                            Click on each title to reveal text.
                                                                                            Continued

                                                                                            How to develop a valid assessment

                                                                                            Developing Vocational SQA Assessments

                                                                                            When developing an assessment, the following high-level process will be followed:

                                                                                            More detailed processes for developing a digital assessment or a paper-based assessment are available from the Digital Assessment Team and the Assessment Support Materials teams respectively.

                                                                                            More appointee training is available on the Academy here(opens in a new tab).

                                                                                            To begin with you must familiarise yourself with the unit specification, its Learning Outcomes and Assessment Criteria. Some units may refer to these as Knowledge and Evidence Requirements, but they serve the same purpose.

                                                                                            When defining assessment content you must consider:
                                                                                                

                                                                                                Is it demanding enough to provide adequate challenge?

                                                                                            1

                                                                                            If you are developing an assessment that covers multiple units, be sure that the content of the units is sufficiently related to make the assessment coherent and meaningful to learners.

                                                                                            You also need to consider the learner; vocational assessments must be set at a level that a minimally competent learner can achieve.

                                                                                            2

                                                                                            Once you have established what has to be assessed, you can start to identify the best assessment methods and decide on what will be acceptable evidence to prove that the assessment task has been successfully carried out and meets the required standard (assessment criteria/evidence requirements).

                                                                                            3

                                                                                            Thought must also be given to the most appropriate assessment method to use, for example asking a learner to write a report on how they would build a wall would not be the most appropriate and VALID assessment method. Rather it would be better to set a practical activity and ask the learner to demonstrate their abilities. This point relates to what naturally occurring evidence would be generated.

                                                                                            4

                                                                                            In some instances, choice of the assessment method may not be at the gift of SQA, assessment methods may be set out in an Assessment Strategy or industry Code of Practice, for example for Street Works qualifications the Highway Authorities and Utilities Committee UK mandate that to gain certification and registration, learners must undergo practical observation and a  20 question multiple choice assessment carried our under exam conditions.

                                                                                            The below is outcome 1 of Unit - H83M 70 Contribute to Health and Safety when Conducting Archaeological Operation. The Unit specification clearly states the learning outcome and the assessment criteria stating the knowledge, understanding, skills and competencies to be assessed.

                                                                                            Furthermore, it stipulates the conditions of assessment and suggests assessment methods.  Unfortunately, not all unit specifications contain such direction and you may be required to use your professional judgement and expertise to determine this.

                                                                                            Learning outcomes
                                                                                            The learner will:
                                                                                            	

                                                                                            Assessment criteria
                                                                                            The learner can:

                                                                                                Be able to operate safely in the workplace
                                                                                            	

                                                                                            1.1 Demonstrate that they can work in a way which avoids creating hazardous situations.
                                                                                            1.2 Identify potential hazards.
                                                                                            1.3 Report potential hazards to the appropriate person.
                                                                                            1.4 Communicate clear information and instructions.
                                                                                            1.5 Demonstrate that they can use tools and equipment safely and in accordance with organisational procedures.
                                                                                            1.6 Demonstrate that they can handle and store work materials and components in accordance with approved procedures.
                                                                                            1.7 Demonstrate that manual handling techniques are used appropriately.
                                                                                            1.8 Demonstrate that they can use appropriate personal protective equipment in compliance with safe working practices.
                                                                                            1.9 Demonstrate that they can report accidents and incidents to an authorised person in accorance with approved procedures.
                                                                                            1.10 Implement work according to approved procedures.

                                                                                            The unit specification clearly states what would be a valid assessment requirements and approach to this unit:

                                                                                            Assessment (evidence) requirements

                                                                                                Assessors must ensure that learners provide evidence to cover all the learning outcomes and assessment criteria.

                                                                                                This unit is designed to assess the skills of learners in the workplace. Evidence of occupational competence should be generated and collected through performance in workplace conditions. This includes the knowledge-based learning outcomes and assessment criteria of the competence units.

                                                                                                These conditions would be those typical to the learners normal place of work. The evidence collected under these conditions should also be as naturally occurring as possible. It is accepted that not all employees have identical workplace conditions and therefore there cannot be assessment conditions that are identical for all learners. However, assessors must ensure that, as far as possible, the conditions for assessment should be those under which the learner usually works.

                                                                                                Collection of evidence of performance can be used to substantiate, support and expand the evidence base for competent performance. This may include:

                                                                                                    Observation

                                                                                                    Product and photographic evidence

                                                                                                    Relevant active documentation, reports, presentations

                                                                                            The full unit specification which includes the assessment information can be found SQA - Unit Search(opens in a new tab) and entering the unit code H83M.

                                                                                            Understand the graded unit specification and Assessment Support Pack (ASP)

                                                                                            Understand the graded unit specification and Assessment Support Pack (ASP)


                                                                                            The graded unit specification is very important and states what the learner has to achieve, and the evidence required in the assessment process. It identifies the standards to which the learner has to perform and provides guidance on teaching and learning approaches. 

                                                                                            The graded unit specification will include:
                                                                                                

                                                                                                support notes and information for learners

                                                                                            Most graded units will have an SQA produced Assessment Support Pack (ASP) which can be found on the secure website. Each ASP contains details of the assessment tasks which will correspond to the requirements set down within the graded unit specification. Your SQA Coordinator can access the secure website and obtain an ASP for you.  It is essential that all ASPs are kept secure.

                                                                                            When using an ASP from SQAs website, it is still the centres responsibility to make sure that all the appropriate internal quality assurance procedures are satisfactorily completed. The centre must check that the assessment(s) (and marking guidelines) are valid, reliable, practicable, equitable and fair.
